channel.title: NYT > Business Day
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: How to Write TV in the Age of Trump: Showrunners Reveal All
item.media:credit: Illustration by Ben Wiseman. Photos by Kevin Winter/Getty Images; Steve Sands/GC Images; Byron Cohen/ABC, via Getty Images; Sarah Shatz/CBS, via Getty Images.
item.description: Shonda Rhimes of “Scandal” and the people behind “Veep,” “Madam Secretary” and “House of Cards” talk about reality bumping into fiction.
item.dc:creator: JIM RUTENBERG

item.title: Wheels: Online Upstarts Seek to Disrupt Used-Car Buying
item.media:description: Emily Hurwitz, 28, purchased a Volkswagen Tiguan through Shift, an online company that brought the car to her apartment for a test drive.
item.media:credit: Peter DaSilva for The New York Times
item.description: Companies like Shift appeal to millennials in particular, but experts say the traditional dealership isn’t about to disappear.
item.dc:creator: MARY M. CHAPMAN

item.title: United Passenger Will Need Reconstructive Surgery, Lawyer Says
item.media:description: Thomas A. Demetrio, a lawyer for Dr. David Dao, blamed a culture of disrespect at United Airlines and overly aggressive tactics from Chicago aviation police for the injuries to his client.
item.description: Dr. David Dao, the passenger dragged off a United flight, suffered a broken nose, sustained a concussion, lost two teeth and injured his sinuses, his lawyer said.
item.dc:creator: MITCH SMITH

item.title: Why ‘Sorry’ Is Still the Hardest Word
item.media:description: Sean Spicer, the White House press secretary, said of his comments favorably comparing Hitler to President Bashar al-Assad of Syria: “I made a mistake; there’s no other way to say it. I got into a topic that I shouldn’t have, and I screwed up.”
item.media:credit: T.J. Kirkpatrick for The New York Times
item.description: The representatives of United Airlines and the White House both found themselves grappling with the increasingly common ritual: the public apology.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL M. GRYNBAUM

item.title: Movers: JPMorgan’s Results May Signal Good News While Wells Fargo Is Flat
item.media:description: Jamie Dimon, chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, speaking before the U.S. Chamber of Commerce this month. On Thursday, the bank reported strong quarterly results.
item.description: We’re following major developments in the markets throughout the day.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Wall Street Dips as Investors Parse Bank Earnings
item.description: Wall Street edged lower on Thursday and looked set to book losses for the third straight day as investors weighed earnings from big U.S. banks and President Donald Trump's comments on the strength of the dollar.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: New Tools Needed to Track Technology’s Impact on Jobs, Panel Says
item.media:description: Automation fears have stirred many fanciful visions of the future. An expert panel calls for new tools of analysis to help workers adapt.
item.description: The nation is “flying blind” into a new era of automation and artificial intelligence, the authors of a National Academies study warned.
item.dc:creator: STEVE LOHR

item.title: BRITAIN’S UNEASY LABOR FORCE: Britain’s Uneasy Labor Market
item.media:description: The scene near the Houses of Parliament in central London after the referendum vote in June.
item.description: Britain’s economy is thriving, and unemployment is at its lowest level since 1975. But new data exposes potential trouble spots.
item.dc:creator: AMIE TSANG

item.title: Trump Reversals Hint at Wall Street Wing’s Sway in White House
item.media:description: President Trump said he no longer wanted to label China a currency manipulator.
item.description: Startling shifts on China and the Export-Import Bank and the possible reappointment of the chairwoman of the Federal Reserve show financiers may be gaining the upper hand over the populists.
item.dc:creator: ALAN RAPPEPORT

item.title: The Murdochs Assess the O’Reilly Damage
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Manhattan on Wednesday called for Fox News to dismiss Bill O’Reilly.
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.description: Bill O’Reilly has left Fox News for a vacation while his employers decide whether they should force him from the network over sexual harassment accusations.
item.dc:creator: EMILY STEEL and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT

item.title: Reality Show Workers Stage a Walkout to Push Contract Talks Forward
item.media:description: The Writers Guild of America, the union that represents Hollywood writers, is battling entertainment companies on multiple fronts.
item.description: At least 100 workers walked out of roughly a dozen reality show companies in an effort to assert the strength of the Writers Guild of America.
item.dc:creator: BROOKS BARNES

item.title: Bigger, Faster, More Lavish: Americans Crave S.U.V.s, and Carmakers Oblige
item.media:description: Ford’s latest Lincoln Navigator is larger and more powerful than its predecessor, while aiming squarely at car owners seeking luxury features.
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.description: At the New York International Auto Show, powerful sport-utility vehicles are at center stage, a sign of the continuing shift away from traditional passenger cars.
item.dc:creator: BILL VLASIC
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks

item.title: Uber Sees an Executive Exodus as It Faces Questions of Workplace Culture
item.media:description: Outside Uber’s headquarters in San Francisco.
item.description: In the last three months, several high-ranking managers have left the ride-hailing company. At least one has been openly critical about the way the company has been run.
item.dc:creator: MIKE ISAAC

item.title: Burger King ‘O.K. Google’ Ad Doesn’t Seem O.K. With Google
item.description: The commercial was a novel but potentially invasive marketing tactic that came as more Americans use voice-activated devices.
item.dc:creator: SAPNA MAHESHWARI

item.title: Venezuela Staves Off Default, but Low Oil Prices Pose a Threat
item.media:description: A demonstration this month in Caracas against the government of President Nicolás Maduro. With its oil production and international reserves falling, the government is struggling to pay for imported medicine and food.
item.description: With dwindling reserves and political turmoil, the government is juggling assets and leaning on its American subsidiary, Citgo, to meet payment needs.
item.dc:creator: CLIFFORD KRAUSS

item.title: Scott Pruitt Faces Anger From Right Over E.P.A. Finding He Won’t Fight
item.media:description: Traffic in New York City. Conservative groups want Scott Pruitt, the head of the Environmental Protection Agency, to overturn a ruling known as the endangerment finding, which provides the legal foundation for the Obama administration’s climate-change policies.
item.description: Critics charge the agency’s administrator should have challenged a legal finding that underpinned the Obama climate policies, but he refuses to budge.
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: Journalists at Gothamist and DNAinfo Agree to Join Labor Union
item.media:description: Joe Ricketts, the owner of DNAinfo and Gothamist, in 2014.
item.description: The news sites merged recently, and DNAinfo has laid off about a quarter of its editorial staff in recent weeks.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: KPMG Fires 6 Over Ethics Breach on Audit Warnings
item.media:description: KPMG said that an individual who had joined the firm from the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board had received confidential information from an employee of the oversight board and shared it with others at KPMG.
item.description: The accounting firm said the employees had been terminated after it learned they were receiving improper warnings of planned audit inspections.
item.dc:creator: CHAD BRAY

item.title: Want to Resist Trump or Make America Great Again? These People Switched Careers
item.media:credit: From left: Jim Wilson/The New York Times; Dustin Chambers for The New York Times; Hiroko Masuike/The New York Times
item.description: The election of Donald J. Trump has provoked elation, outrage and self-reflection. It has even prompted career changes.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GELLES

item.title: A Healthy Nudge: How Behavioral Economics Can Produce Better Health Care
item.media:description: Handwashing is important for doctors, and sometimes they need nudges to do it.
item.media:credit: Jeff Swensen for The New York Times
item.description: People don’t always act “rationally.” Nudges might be able to lead to better doctors and healthier patients.
item.dc:creator: DHRUV KHULLAR

item.title: After Campaign Exit, Manafort Borrowed From Businesses With Trump Ties
item.media:description: Paul Manafort’s transactions raise a number of questions, including whether his decision to turn to lenders connected to Donald J. Trump was related to his role in the campaign.
item.description: A shell company created by Paul Manafort the same day he left the presidential campaign quickly received $13 million in loans from the businesses.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McINTIRE

item.title: A Chat With a Live Streamer Is Yours, for a Price
item.media:description: Andre Rebelo, live-streams his Grand Theft Auto 5 Mods game at home in Vancouver.
item.media:credit: Rafal Gerszak for The New York Times
item.description: Dedicated video streaming platforms like YouTube and Twitch are looking for ways to sweeten the deal for streamers so they produce more live content.
item.dc:creator: LAURA PARKER

item.title: State of the Art: How Technology Has Failed to Improve Your Airline Experience
item.media:description: United Airlines planes at San Francisco International Airport. Oscar Munoz, United’s chief executive, offered an apology and pledged to review the airline’s policies two days after a passenger was violently ejected from an overbooked flight.
item.description: Silicon Valley prides itself on its capacity to upend entrenched industries. But airlines have eluded tech disruption.
item.dc:creator: FARHAD MANJOO

item.title: Tech We're Using: The Apps That Make Keeping Up With Soccer Easier
item.media:description: Rory Smith using his Apple iPad outside Stamford Bridge, home of Chelsea FC, in London.
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.description: The video-streaming apps Virgin Anywhere and Sky Sports Mobile TV are a boon for a soccer reporter, or a fan.
item.dc:creator: RORY SMITH

item.title: Trilobites: A Lizard With Scales That Behave Like a Computer Simulation
item.media:description: An ocellated lizard. Their scales change from brown and white to black and green as they get older, and scientists say they appear to follow a pattern that is similar to a computer simulation.
item.description: Two mathematical models converge to illuminate the process through which an ocellated lizard’s scales repeatedly change color.
item.dc:creator: STEPH YIN

item.title: Your Money Adviser: Medical Debt: You May Not Owe It
item.description: Researchers find that about 60 percent of complaints about medical debt collections fall into categories that suggest the consumers may not owe the money.
item.dc:creator: ANN CARRNS

item.title: Feature: Mike Judge, the Bard of Suck
item.media:description: Mike Judge.
item.media:credit: Chris Buck for The New York Times
item.description: From “Idiocracy” to “Silicon Valley,” the writer and director has established himself as America’s foremost chronicler of its own self-destructive tendencies.
item.dc:creator: WILLY STALEY

item.title: Trump’s Trademark Continues Its March Across the Globe, Raising Eyebrows
item.media:description: Trump home goods have sold briskly in Lima, Peru. Officials say his trademark applications have gotten no special treatment.
item.media:credit: Santiago Barco Luna for The New York Times
item.description: Whether 157 pending applications in 36 countries risk violating the Constitution is an open question, as no president has tested the limits like Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: SHARON LaFRANIERE and DANNY HAKIM

item.title: Tech Tip: Send Some Sass With That Text Message
item.description: Apple’s own texting app for iOS 10 includes easy ways to liven up your interactions with other iMessage users.
item.dc:creator: J. D. BIERSDORFER
